update.description:
Add scoring scripts for qual1 and qual2.

Instructions have been added to the wiki and will need to be updated when this is merged:

* [Qual1](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/qual_task1)
* [Qual2](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/qual_task2)
update.title: Scoring

content.raw:
Thanks for the answer. 
Knowing that this is the cause I can run it on a computer that supports the gpu_ray so w3 don't have to modify anything.
content.html: Thanks for the answer. Knowing that this is the cause I can run it on a computer that supports the gpu_ray so w3 don't have to modify anything.

content.raw:
I just commented on that issue. We won't change the model of the console because:

1. It would be unfair to other participants.
1. Changing the simulation environment and models is not supported.
content.html:
I just commented on that issue. We won't change the model of the console because:

  1. It would be unfair to other participants.
  2. Changing the simulation environment and models is not supported.

content.raw: I was forced to use RAY instead of gpu_ray as suggested here #!/osrf/srcsim/issues/50/no-valid-multisense-lidar-data
content.html: I was forced to use RAY instead of gpu_ray as suggested here #!/osrf/srcsim/issues/50/no-valid-multisense-lidar-data

content.raw: The multisense model uses the `gpu_ray` sensor, which will report distances to visual objects.
content.html: The multisense model uses the gpu_ray sensor, which will report distances to visual objects.

content.raw:
You're right, I can confirm that the collision shape for the console is way in front of those buttons:

![consolecollision.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1886244211-consolecollision.png)
content.html: You're right, I can confirm that the collision shape for the console is way in front of those buttons:

content.raw:
@chapulina I have been using qual1 scoring, and while for most of the buttons my detected position matches the ground truth, some of the buttons always have an error of 14cm in Z. 

I plotted the ground truth on rviz, and saw that the ground truth for the  buttons below the 3 big screens is way behind what the laser detects. Please see the attached screenshots.

The yellow dots are the ground truth on the head frame (same happens with upperNeckPitchLink), the red and purple dots is the spinning laser scan. 

As you can see the ground truth for the buttons around the keyboard matches pretty well the point where the laser scan hits the console. For the buttons around the big screen it does not, they are reported 14-15cm behind the position where the laser scan hits the console.

https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2791822590-Screenshot%20from%202017-01-03%2011:52:14.png

https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2754149116-Screenshot%20from%202017-01-03%2011:51:54.png
content.html:
@chapulina I have been using qual1 scoring, and while for most of the buttons my detected position matches the ground truth, some of the buttons always have an error of 14cm in Z.

I plotted the ground truth on rviz, and saw that the ground truth for the buttons below the 3 big screens is way behind what the laser detects. Please see the attached screenshots.

The yellow dots are the ground truth on the head frame (same happens with upperNeckPitchLink), the red and purple dots is the spinning laser scan.

As you can see the ground truth for the buttons around the keyboard matches pretty well the point where the laser scan hits the console. For the buttons around the big screen it does not, they are reported 14-15cm behind the position where the laser scan hits the console.

https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2791822590-Screenshot%20from%202017-01-03%2011:52:14.png

https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2754149116-Screenshot%20from%202017-01-03%2011:51:54.png

content.raw: That's a good question.  I've been assuming it is in the center, on the top surface.
content.html: That's a good question. I've been assuming it is in the center, on the top surface.

content.raw: A basic question is what is 'position' of the button? Is it the center, a corner, or what?
content.html: A basic question is what is 'position' of the button? Is it the center, a corner, or what?

content.raw:
I decided to go back to basics and not invert the image and then just do the most basic of transforms, just camera to head.  With that, my answers agree with the head frame (not head frame flipped) result in scoring.
So we're good for now.   I'm going to mark issue #25 resolved.
[Louise](https://bitbucket.org/chapulina/), thanks for the excellent work.
content.html: I decided to go back to basics and not invert the image and then just do the most basic of transforms, just camera to head. With that, my answers agree with the head frame (not head frame flipped) result in scoring. So we're good for now. I'm going to mark issue #25 resolved. Louise, thanks for the excellent work.

content.raw:
That is what I see too.  So looks like there is an issue with the head frame Y position being offset in Gazebo vs ROS.
Maybe it doesn't matter, since we are getting OK results with the ROS transforms (see below, mine works now too).
Still, I suspect it has implications for moving around in the Gazebo world in phase 2.
content.html: That is what I see too. So looks like there is an issue with the head frame Y position being offset in Gazebo vs ROS. Maybe it doesn't matter, since we are getting OK results with the ROS transforms (see below, mine works now too). Still, I suspect it has implications for moving around in the Gazebo world in phase 2.

content.raw: Rviz reports the head at 0.13412; -0.060505; 1.6132 with the world frame selected.
content.html: Rviz reports the head at 0.13412; -0.060505; 1.6132 with the world frame selected.

content.raw:
interesting-- I must be doing something wrong.  But there is an offset between gazebo world and ROS home and Louise found at least part of it in the pelvis coordinates.
What do you get for the ROS head frame (0,0,0) to world transform?
content.html: interesting-- I must be doing something wrong. But there is an offset between gazebo world and ROS home and Louise found at least part of it in the pelvis coordinates. What do you get for the ROS head frame (0,0,0) to world transform?

content.raw: This is behavior we noticed and where trying to correct for as well. However being told that we are not suppose to subscribe to or use gazebo topics it makes it quite hard to find what that deviation is. Our scoring for qual1 is coming in pretty close, generally within this deviation. I am not sure if we should be trying to push those scores all the way down to zero or if being within that deviation for qual 1 is acceptable.
content.html: This is behavior we noticed and where trying to correct for as well. However being told that we are not suppose to subscribe to or use gazebo topics it makes it quite hard to find what that deviation is. Our scoring for qual1 is coming in pretty close, generally within this deviation. I am not sure if we should be trying to push those scores all the way down to zero or if being within that deviation for qual 1 is acceptable.

content.raw: yes, the neck transforms seem to line up, whew.
content.html: yes, the neck transforms seem to line up, whew.

content.raw:
I don't see anything in the original competition description that says we'd be working with Gazebo. It's just the simulation environment. All the work should be in ROS. But as you say, this should have been figured out before Sept. 

It may be that the actual scoring will use the ROS frames. Louise can you say?

This script is just an approximation of the score.
content.html:
I don't see anything in the original competition description that says we'd be working with Gazebo. It's just the simulation environment. All the work should be in ROS. But as you say, this should have been figured out before Sept.

It may be that the actual scoring will use the ROS frames. Louise can you say?

This script is just an approximation of the score.

content.raw: Except we have to work closely with Gazebo in Phase 2, so that is part of the process.  The most unambiguous answer is actually Gazebo world coordinates, as those are straightforward to check answers against.  If the answer script has to get into ROS frames to evaluate the score, then there could be all sorts of problems making sure that it is correct.  Nevertheless, this certainly should have been considered a long time ago, before the contest began.
content.html: Except we have to work closely with Gazebo in Phase 2, so that is part of the process. The most unambiguous answer is actually Gazebo world coordinates, as those are straightforward to check answers against. If the answer script has to get into ROS frames to evaluate the score, then there could be all sorts of problems making sure that it is correct. Nevertheless, this certainly should have been considered a long time ago, before the contest began.

content.raw:
Great find!  This was exactly my concern from the very beginning when I saw that we were going to have to do transforms that were not included in the ROS tf.  It gets really messy. 
In any case, what frame do you think we should publish in?
Seems like it could be ROS head frame, ROS neck frame, or Gazebo neck frame.
As long as one gets picked soon and we stick with it, I'm good.

I decided I better check the rotation frames too.  The rotation from ROS head frame to Gazebo world has nonzero values in both roll (expected because it is inverted) and pitch.  What to do about the pitch offset?
It's especially confusing because the Gazebo model has no head frame.  The neck pitch in the Valkyrie model is set to 0.


```
#!python

head frame (0,0,0) becomes world frame: X, Y, Z = 0.103639, -0.045790, 1.615896
head frame (0,0,0) becomes world frame: roll, pitch, yaw = 3.141456, 0.129107, -0.000327
```
content.html:
Great find! This was exactly my concern from the very beginning when I saw that we were going to have to do transforms that were not included in the ROS tf. It gets really messy. In any case, what frame do you think we should publish in? Seems like it could be ROS head frame, ROS neck frame, or Gazebo neck frame. As long as one gets picked soon and we stick with it, I'm good.

I decided I better check the rotation frames too. The rotation from ROS head frame to Gazebo world has nonzero values in both roll (expected because it is inverted) and pitch. What to do about the pitch offset? It's especially confusing because the Gazebo model has no head frame. The neck pitch in the Valkyrie model is set to 0.

head frame (0,0,0) becomes world frame: X, Y, Z = 0.103639, -0.045790, 1.615896
head frame (0,0,0) becomes world frame: roll, pitch, yaw = 3.141456, 0.129107, -0.000327

content.raw: I feel that for this it should be a transform that can be done with ROS and with no additional calculations. The purpose is to see if we know ROS.
content.html: I feel that for this it should be a transform that can be done with ROS and with no additional calculations. The purpose is to see if we know ROS.

content.raw:
You're right, it looks like the Gazebo world frame is different from the ROS world frame. The pelvis is centered in Gazebo:

~~~
$ gz model -p -m valkyrie
-0.033887 -0.001069 0.983162 -6.6e-05 -0.003811 -0.002758
~~~

but for ROS it's not:

~~~
$ rosrun tf tf_echo /world /pelvis
At time 239.296
- Translation: [-0.011, -0.026, 0.983]
- Rotation: in Quaternion [-0.000, -0.002, -0.002, 1.000]
            in RPY (radian) [-0.000, -0.004, -0.003]
            in RPY (degree) [-0.002, -0.217, -0.195]
~~~

There might be another fixed joint reduction somewhere.
content.html:
You're right, it looks like the Gazebo world frame is different from the ROS world frame. The pelvis is centered in Gazebo:

$ gz model -p -m valkyrie
-0.033887 -0.001069 0.983162 -6.6e-05 -0.003811 -0.002758

but for ROS it's not:

$ rosrun tf tf_echo /world /pelvis
At time 239.296
- Translation: [-0.011, -0.026, 0.983]
- Rotation: in Quaternion [-0.000, -0.002, -0.002, 1.000]
            in RPY (radian) [-0.000, -0.004, -0.003]
            in RPY (degree) [-0.002, -0.217, -0.195]

There might be another fixed joint reduction somewhere.

Looks like we found the Y offset. I get those values by transforming (0,0,0) in the head frame to the world frame using a transform listener (listen_). It is almost the first step in the entire program. Here is the code (in the actual code, this is wrapped in a try/catch), assuming that the transform listener has been initialized and passed as listener_

geometry_msgs::PointStamped zeroPointWorldFrame, zeroPointHeadFrame_;
    zeroPointHeadFrame_.point.x = 0.0;
    zeroPointHeadFrame_.point.y = 0.0;
    zeroPointHeadFrame_.point.z = 0.0;
    zeroPointHeadFrame_.header.frame_id = "head";
    zeroPointHeadFrame_.header.stamp = ros::Time();
listener_.transformPoint("world", zeroPointHeadFrame_, zeroPointWorldFrame);

content.raw:
1. It looks like you skipped the filtering step where you're supposed to filter `state.log` to get `qual_1.log`.

1. Yes, the lights won't flash during log playback.

1. Yes, that command could be added to the wiki. But since the lights won't flash, it might not be very useful for qual 1...
content.html:
1. It looks like you skipped the filtering step where you're supposed to filter state.log to get qual_1.log.

  2. Yes, the lights won't flash during log playback.

  3. Yes, that command could be added to the wiki. But since the lights won't flash, it might not be very useful for qual 1...

content.raw:
That was the problem. Suggest making it clear that the step must be done before trying to score. It wasn't clear to me that it was necessary. 

Remember, computers are dumber than people but smarter than programmers.

content.raw:
I'm having problems with scoring. The state.log is just 23.3 MB which seems small based on other reports. The qual1 log looks correct. I've done multiple runs and get the same results.

Here is the command line and the errors:


```
#!text

./scoring_q1.rb ~/src_qual1_2016-12-22T15:58:12.201673.log     ~/.gazebo/log/2016-12-22T15:58:12.198123/gzserver/state.log
Couldn't find pose for path //sdf/world/model[@name='console1']/pose
Couldn't find pose for path //sdf/world/model/link/visual[@name='light1']/pose
./scoring_q1.rb:97:in `block in initialize': undefined method `*' for nil:NilClass (NoMethodError)
	from ./scoring_q1.rb:91:in `each'
	from ./scoring_q1.rb:91:in `initialize'
	from ./scoring_q1.rb:178:in `new'
	from ./scoring_q1.rb:178:in `<main>'

```
*Comment: The qual1 wiki command line says the gazebo log is qual1.log but should say state.log. Text earlier on the page says it correctly as the state.log.*

I also ran a playback of the gazebo log. It ran but I didn't see any of the lights during the playback. Is that correct behavior?



```
#!text
rosrun gazebo_ros gazebo -p ~/.gazebo/log/2016-12-22T15:58:12.198123/gzserver/state.log

```
*Comment: The qual1 wiki page doesn't have the "rosrun gazebo_ros" for this command line. MIght also mention that roscore needs to be run.*

My commands for the qual1 run are:

```
#!text

source /opt/nasa/indigo/setup.bash
roslaunch srcsim qual1.launch  extra_gazebo_args:="-r" init:="true"
```

content.raw: How are you getting these values? For me the head position in the world frame is about `[0.1305 -0.0001 1.6135]` after landing.
content.html: How are you getting these values? For me the head position in the world frame is about [0.1305 -0.0001 1.6135] after landing.

content.raw:
I checked the ROS head frame to Gazebo world frame transform and it depends on how the robot lands when the harness is detached, but generally is around these values:

```
#!python

head frame XYZ: 0, 0, 0 becomes world frame XYZ: 0.136740, -0.047332, 1.617657
```
and that -0.47 Y offset is around half of the offset difference I am seeing in the answers.  Can you check the world -> head frame?
content.html:
I checked the ROS head frame to Gazebo world frame transform and it depends on how the robot lands when the harness is detached, but generally is around these values:

head frame XYZ: 0, 0, 0 becomes world frame XYZ: 0.136740, -0.047332, 1.617657

and that -0.47 Y offset is around half of the offset difference I am seeing in the answers. Can you check the world -> head frame?

#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/qual_task1

content.raw:
The new one is looking good in X and Z.  I am still seeing an offset in Y however.  The offset is about .07 m and, as it turns out, that is the same as the camera baseline.
I get the image in the left camera optical frame and transform it to the head frame.  That transform moves Y by 1/2 the camera baseline.  So if there is an issue with the head frame being inverted, it would move it by 1/2 the camera baseline in the wrong direction, which would offset the result by 2 * (1/2 camera baseline) which is exactly what I see. It comes out correct in rviz.  However, the scoring result for the neck frame agrees with the scoring result for the inverted head frame, so I don't know what is happening.


```
#!python

Answer 6: Color:    answer                         [1.0000 0.0000 0.0000]
                    ground truth                   [1.0000 0.0000 0.0000]
                    euclidean error                [0.000000]
          Position: answer                         [2.8357 0.6229 -0.0833]
                    ground truth (neck)            [2.9775 0.5473 -0.3765]
                    ground truth (head)            [2.8290 -0.5473 0.0833]
                    ground truth (head flipped)    [2.8290 0.5473 -0.0833]
                    euclidean error (neck)         [0.334340]
                    euclidean error (head)         [1.182004]
                    euclidean error (head flipped) [0.075867]
```
content.html:
The new one is looking good in X and Z. I am still seeing an offset in Y however. The offset is about .07 m and, as it turns out, that is the same as the camera baseline. I get the image in the left camera optical frame and transform it to the head frame. That transform moves Y by 1/2 the camera baseline. So if there is an issue with the head frame being inverted, it would move it by 1/2 the camera baseline in the wrong direction, which would offset the result by 2 * (1/2 camera baseline) which is exactly what I see. It comes out correct in rviz. However, the scoring result for the neck frame agrees with the scoring result for the inverted head frame, so I don't know what is happening.

Answer 6: Color:    answer                         [1.0000 0.0000 0.0000]
                    ground truth                   [1.0000 0.0000 0.0000]
                    euclidean error                [0.000000]
          Position: answer                         [2.8357 0.6229 -0.0833]
                    ground truth (neck)            [2.9775 0.5473 -0.3765]
                    ground truth (head)            [2.8290 -0.5473 0.0833]
                    ground truth (head flipped)    [2.8290 0.5473 -0.0833]
                    euclidean error (neck)         [0.334340]
                    euclidean error (head)         [1.182004]
                    euclidean error (head flipped) [0.075867]

content.raw: I am working on some images for the wiki.
content.html: I am working on some images for the wiki.

content.raw:
When this is all sorted out please be sure it gets explained fully on the qual1 web page. I've been following these comments but their location is not obvious. Even knowing this thread I had to hunt for it late last night. 

Personally, if the standard transforms aren't handling the inverted image situation those transforms are wrong and should be fixed. 

I'll be chiming in with my own results shortly. Just got the transforms and console messages working last night so am ready to test my outputs.
content.html:
When this is all sorted out please be sure it gets explained fully on the qual1 web page. I've been following these comments but their location is not obvious. Even knowing this thread I had to hunt for it late last night.

Personally, if the standard transforms aren't handling the inverted image situation those transforms are wrong and should be fixed.

I'll be chiming in with my own results shortly. Just got the transforms and console messages working last night so am ready to test my outputs.

update.title: Scoring

content.raw:
I think we are getting closer.......
Here are a couple answers with their score:
This is switch 32, which is below and to the left of the head.  Below means z should be negative, left means y should be positive.  That is the case for my answer and the real values for the neck frame.  The real values for the head frame are inverted, which is probably because the head frame is indeed inverted, but goes against what we heard earlier, which was to report in the frame that is correct for the robot facing the upright console.  I don't know why my Y value answers are offset vs. the real values.  I suspect that there is a glitch in going from ROS to Gazebo, since those Y values are perfect for where the lights are in rviz.  It could also have to do with inverting the image, since the process for that is a bit arbitrary and if it is not rotated around the exact center, then offsets may occur.

```
#!python

Answer 9: Color:    answer                 [0.0000 0.0000 1.0000]
                    ground truth           [0.0000 0.0000 1.0000]
                    euclidean error        [0.000000]
          Position: answer                 [2.8123 0.5305 0.0464]
                    ground truth (neck)    [3.0009 0.4622 -0.2463]
                    ground truth (head)    [2.8351 -0.4622 -0.0489]
                    euclidean error (neck) [0.354727]
                    euclidean error (head) [0.997496]
```


This next one is switch 34, which is lined up below switch 32.  So the y should be the same and the z should be more negative.  Again true for my answer and for the real neck frame.  The real answer in the head frame moves in the positive direction for z.  Note that all three show a magnitude change in z of 0.13, which is correct.

```
#!python

Answer 7: Color:    answer                 [0.0000 1.0000 0.0000]
                    ground truth           [0.0000 1.0000 0.0000]
                    euclidean error        [0.000000]
          Position: answer                 [2.8240 0.5325 -0.0830]
                    ground truth (neck)    [2.9800 0.4623 -0.3764]
                    ground truth (head)    [2.8315 -0.4623 0.0829]]
```
I'm fine with reporting in whatever frame you think is best, but I need to know what to submit for the actual entry.
content.html:
I think we are getting closer....... Here are a couple answers with their score: This is switch 32, which is below and to the left of the head. Below means z should be negative, left means y should be positive. That is the case for my answer and the real values for the neck frame. The real values for the head frame are inverted, which is probably because the head frame is indeed inverted, but goes against what we heard earlier, which was to report in the frame that is correct for the robot facing the upright console. I don't know why my Y value answers are offset vs. the real values. I suspect that there is a glitch in going from ROS to Gazebo, since those Y values are perfect for where the lights are in rviz. It could also have to do with inverting the image, since the process for that is a bit arbitrary and if it is not rotated around the exact center, then offsets may occur.

Answer 9: Color:    answer                 [0.0000 0.0000 1.0000]
                    ground truth           [0.0000 0.0000 1.0000]
                    euclidean error        [0.000000]
          Position: answer                 [2.8123 0.5305 0.0464]
                    ground truth (neck)    [3.0009 0.4622 -0.2463]
                    ground truth (head)    [2.8351 -0.4622 -0.0489]
                    euclidean error (neck) [0.354727]
                    euclidean error (head) [0.997496]

This next one is switch 34, which is lined up below switch 32. So the y should be the same and the z should be more negative. Again true for my answer and for the real neck frame. The real answer in the head frame moves in the positive direction for z. Note that all three show a magnitude change in z of 0.13, which is correct.

Answer 7: Color:    answer                 [0.0000 1.0000 0.0000]
                    ground truth           [0.0000 1.0000 0.0000]

I'm fine with reporting in whatever frame you think is best, but I need to know what to submit for the actual entry.

content.raw: So instead of changing from world to head frame, I changed to both head frame and neck frame. I hope that doesn't add to the confusion.
content.html: So instead of changing from world to head frame, I changed to both head frame and neck frame. I hope that doesn't add to the confusion.

                    ground truth           [1.0000 0.0000 0.0000]
                    euclidean error        [1.414214]
          Position: answer                 [2.5900 -0.4200 -0.6000]
                    ground truth (neck)    [2.6013 -0.4091 -0.6288]
                    ground truth (head)    [2.4890 0.4091 0.3825]

update.title: Scoring

content.raw:
World frame is helpful because it is unambiguous and eliminates the concern over the image being inverted and also perhaps differences between ROS and Gazebo.  Either way is OK.  I guess reporting in head frame shows output that matches the answers file generated during the run, maybe makes it easier to compare.  
By the way, the code is well written and organized-- nice work!
content.html:
World frame is helpful because it is unambiguous and eliminates the concern over the image being inverted and also perhaps differences between ROS and Gazebo. Either way is OK. I guess reporting in head frame shows output that matches the answers file generated during the run, maybe makes it easier to compare.
By the way, the code is well written and organized-- nice work!

content.raw: As mentioned in issue #29, both `head` and `upperNeckPitchLink` will be accepted. The scripts will be updated.
content.html: As mentioned in issue #29, both head and upperNeckPitchLink will be accepted. The scripts will be updated.

content.raw: I realize now that reporting the positions in the world frame is not really helpful. I'll change the script to use the head frame.
content.html: I realize now that reporting the positions in the world frame is not really helpful. I'll change the script to use the head frame.

content.raw: Sure enough, the numbers are in world frame.  Now it makes sense, the values may not line up because the answer was reported in the head frame but it was being transformed from the upperNeckPitchLink frame to the world frame instead of from head frame to world frame.  Should be an easy fix.
content.html: Sure enough, the numbers are in world frame. Now it makes sense, the values may not line up because the answer was reported in the head frame but it was being transformed from the upperNeckPitchLink frame to the world frame instead of from head frame to world frame. Should be an easy fix.
